page.title: 09Steeple Barton
page.content: The area is characterised by broadly rolling farmland at about 450ft OD falling away to the Cherwell valley in the east and dissected by the River Dorn and its tributary the Cockley Brook in the west. The soil is cornbrash, deeply stained by iron in the northern half, with outcrops of sand to the north of Horsehay Farm and alluvium in the valleys; considerable deposits of glacial clay occur as scattered pockets. The area has escaped the worst effects of intensive modern agriculture and the fields, resulting from the Enclosures Act, are small with many intact heges. Although woodland is sparse the river valleys are rich in wildlife due to diverse habitats of marsh and old pasture.
